{{more footnotes|date=March 2010}} {{Infobox protected area | name = Los Alcornocales Natural Park | alt_name = Parque natural de Los Alcornocales | iucn_category = V | photo = ElPicacho.jpg | photo_alt = | photo_caption = El Picacho | photo_width = | map = Spain Andalusia | map_alt = | map_caption = Map of [[Andalusia]] | map_width = | location = [[C√°diz (province)|C√°diz]] and [[M√°laga (province)|M√°laga]] provinces
[[Andalusia]], [[Spain]] | nearest_city = | coordinates = {{coord|36.43|N|5.56|W|region:ES|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | coords_ref = {{Cite web |url= http://protectedplanet.net/sites/Los_Alcornocales_Nature_Park |title= Los Alcornocales Nature Park |work=protectedplanet.net}} | area = {{Convert|1677|km2|abbr=on}} | established = 1989 | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | governing_body = | world_heritage_site = | url = }} [[Image:Alcornoques.jpg|thumb|220px|right|Cork oaks]] '''Los Alcornocales Natural Park''' (in Spanish, '''Parque natural de Los Alcornocales''') is a [[natural park (Spain)|natural park]] located in the south of [[Spain]], in the autonomous community of [[Andalusia]]; it is shared between the provinces of [[C√°diz (province)|C√°diz]] and [[M√°laga (province)|M√°laga]]. The natural park occupies a territory spanning seventeen municipalities with a total population of about 380,000. "Los Alcornocales" means "the cork oak groves". Nearly all of the uninhabited land in the park is covered by Mediterranean native forest. While some of the land has been cleared for cattle ranches, much of the human activity in the park is devoted to exploitation of the forest's resources: [[hunting]] wild game, collecting [[Mushroom hunting|wild mushrooms]], and foraging for good specimens of [[tree heath]]. The tree heath (''Erica arborea'', called "brezos" in Spanish) is a small evergreen shrub, rarely more than two or three meters high; it is the source of the reddish briar-root wood used in making tobacco pipes, and its wood is excellent raw material for making [[charcoal]]. Above all, however, the park's forests are exploited for the production of [[Cork (material)|cork]]. The [[cork oak]] (''Quercus suber'') is a tree with a spongy layer of material lying between the outer surface of its bark and the underlying living layer called the ''[[phloem]]'' (which, in turn, encloses the non-living woody stem.) Cork is generated by a specialized layer of tissue called ''[[cork cambium]]''. Properly done, harvesting cork from a given tree can be undertaken every ten to twelve years without damaging the tree; the cork cambium simply regenerates it. Cork has many commercial uses, including wine-bottle stoppers, bulletin boards, coasters, insulation, sealing material for jar lids, flooring, gaskets for engines, fishing bobbers, handles for fishing rods and tennis rackets, etc. ==Climate== Given the geographic position of Los Alcornocales, the dominant climate in the zone is, logically, [[Mediterranean climate|Mediterranean]], but a series of factors contribute to its uniqueness. Its close proximity to the sea helps keep the temperature relatively mild all year long. The average rainfall usually reaches over 800 L/m¬≤, with certain zones receiving more than 1,400 L/m¬≤ thanks to the ocean front. In the mountain ranges to the south, there are great fogs known as the ''barbas del Levante'' (the beards of the east wind). These fogs provide the humidity to form precipitation during the long dry seasons that usually characterize Mediterranean climates. The strong East wind is known as El Levante, and is associated with high temperatures. The wind from the West, which frequently brings rain, is known as El Poniente. These winds make this area one of the best places to construct [[wind farm]]s in all of Spain. ==Flora== [[Image:Korkeiche Andalusien2004.jpg|thumb|Trunk of a cork tree]] The park is characterized by the most extensive forest of cork in Spain and one of the largest in the world. In contrast to the mountains of cork in other latitudes where the tree density is low, in this zone the trees form an authentic forest with a rich variety of shrub and herbaceous vegetation intimately connected. This assures a natural regeneration of the forest, a good mix of ages, and a high level of floral and animal [[biodiversity]]. Forests and smaller wooded areas within the park are comprised mainly by [[Cork oak|cork oaks]] (''Quercus suber''), [[Portuguese oak|Portuguese oaks]] (''Quercus faginea''), [[Pyrenean oak]]s (''Quercus pyrenaica''), [[Olive|olive trees]] (''Olea europaea''), [[alder]]s (''Alnus glutinosa''), [[Holly|holly trees]] (''Ilex aquifolium''), [[Bay laurel|bay laurels]] (''Laurus nobilis''), [[Rhododendron ponticum|rhododendrons]] (''Rhododendron ponticum''), [[fern]]s, [[moss]]es, and [[lichen]]s. ==Fauna== *[[Stork]]s (white, ''Ciconia ciconia''; black, ''Ciconia nigra'') *[[Kite (bird)|Kites]] (black-winged, ''Elanus caeruleus''; red, ''Milvus milvus''; black, ''Milvus migrans'') *[[Common buzzard|Buzzards]] (''Buteo buteo'') *[[Spanish imperial eagle|Spanish imperial eagles]] (''Aquila adalberti'') *[[Vulture]]s (Eurasian black, ''Aegypius monachus''; griffon, ''Gyps fulvus''; Egyptian, ''Neophron percnopterus'') *[[Egyptian mongoose]]s (''Herpestes ichneumon'') *[[Common genet|Common genets]] (''Genetta genetta'') *[[Otter|European otters]] (''Lutra lutra'') *[[European polecat|European polecats]] (''Mustela putorius'') *[[Wild cat|Wildcats]] (''Felis silvestris'') *[[Weasels]] (''Mustela nivalis'') *[[Iberian lynx|Iberian lynxes]] (''Lynx pardina'') *[[Roe deer]] (''Capreolus capreolus'') *[[Fallow deer]] (''Dama dama'') ==History== The cork oak groves of Los Alcornocales are situated in a strategic place. They sit astride two important axes, one an east-west axis, the other north-south. The land here has allegiances to both the [[Atlantic Ocean]] and the [[Mediterranean Sea]]; similarly, it forms the throat of a bridge between [[Europe]] and [[Africa]], a bridge broken only by the narrow [[Strait of Gibraltar]]. Its geographic position is the circumstance, as much as its climate, topography, or suitability for agriculture, that has dictated its patrimony. [[Image:CorchoAlcornocales.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Cork collected from oaks]] The area has been populated for tens of thousands of years. This is attested by the presence of archaeological remnants of settlements by [[Neanderthal]]s dating back more than thirty thousand years, as well as stone implements, engravings, and cave paintings from both the [[Paleolithic]] and [[Neolithic]] ages. Of the greatest interest to visitors, however, are the Bronze Age cave dwellings that dot the area. Of more than fifty caves discovered so far, there are three that have special artistic value: the Cueva del Tajo de las Figuras (Cave of the Figures on the Precipice), which has been compared to the [[Sistine Chapel]] among examples of cave art; the Cave of the High Laja, that houses pictures of the earliest-known boats to ply the Mediterranean; and the [[Cave of Bacinete]], with more than a hundred pictographic representations in a magnificent state of conservation. Later in history, a succession of civilizations and cultures, one superimposed on the next, has dominated this area, all of whom have contributed to its ethnological character. Each has left its marks on the landscape; there are megal√≠thic monuments, Iberian, Phoenician, and Roman ruins, Arab strongholds, etc. Many of the towns that today comprise the park reached their highest state of civilization during the Muslim [[Nasrid dynasty]], when this area was on the western fringe of the [[Kingdom of Granada]]. Today, in this area, many examples of the architecture introduced during the period of Muslim occupation survive; among them are the unique [[White Towns of Andalusia]]. [[Jimena de la Frontera]], [[Castellar de la Frontera]], and [[Medina Sidonia]] are magnificent examples. ==Caves== The '''Cueva del Tajo de las Figuras''', located near the town of [[Benalup-Casas Viejas]], belongs to the group of paleolithic and neolithic sites in southern [[Spain]] that have examples of rock art that the Spanish call "[[art sure√±o]]" (southern art). In 1913, [[Juan Cabr√©]] and [[Eduardo Hern√°ndez-Pacheco]] began the first systematic studies of "art sure√±o" at this cave. The paintings are mostly representations of birds and odd four-footed man-like figures dating from neolithic times. [[Image:Tajo-x.jpg|left|thumb|Cave painting of deer at Tajo de las Figuras]] In 1924 the ''Cueva del Tajo de las Figuras'' was declared an Artistic Architectonic Monument by the Spanish state. For several decades, in order that visitors might better able to discern the paintings on the wall, tour guides have repeatedly sprayed water on them. This practice has resulted in the deposition of layers of lime on the paintings. Beginning in 2005, an effort to restore them was undertaken. {{-}} ==The ecological disaster at La Janda== [[Image:Grus grus 1 (Marek Szczepanek).jpg|250px|right|thumb|A Eurasian crane]] Near the ''Cueva del Tajo de las Figuras'' was the ancient ''Laguna de la Janda'', a haven where millions of birds, both resident and migratory species, found a suitable habitat for feeding and reproduction. Unfortunately, during the middle part of the twentieth century, this important ecological niche was destroyed. To support local rice-growing, water from the lagoon and its associated fresh-water wetlands was diverted, and the area dried up almost completely. In the process, the last reproductive Spanish population of the [[Common crane|Eurasian crane]] (''Grus grus'') was lost as well. ==Towns and cities within the park== [[Image:RutaMolinos.jpg|thumb|Path near [[Alcal√° de los Gazules]]]] All or part of sixteen municipalities of the [[C√°diz (province)|Province of C√°diz]] lie within the Natural Park of Los Alcornocales : [[Alcal√° de los Gazules]], [[Algar, C√°diz|Algar]], [[Algeciras]], [[Arcos de la Frontera]], [[Benalup-Casas Viejas]], [[Benaocaz]], [[Castellar de la Frontera]], [[El Bosque, C√°diz|El Bosque]], [[Jerez de la Frontera]], [[Jimena de la Frontera]], [[Los Barrios]], [[Medina-Sidonia]], [[Prado del Rey]], [[San Jos√© del Valle]], [[Tarifa]] and [[Ubrique]]. Likewise, there is one town in M√°laga province, [[Cortes de la Frontera]], that has land within park boundaries. There are lots of paths connecting these municipalities, nowadays used for [[hiking]]. ==See also== *[[Cork (material)|Cork as a commercial material]] *[[Forests of the Iberian Peninsula]] *[[List of Sites of Community Importance in Andalusia]] ==References== {{Reflist}} == Bibliography == * Acosta, Pillar: ‚ÄúThe schematic cave painting in Spain‚Äù, Faculty of Philosophy and Letters of the University of Salamanca, Salamanca, 1968 * Bergmann, Lothar: ‚ÄúTreatment of images: Applications in the investigation of Rock Art‚Äù, COMPUTER, Magazine of computer science diffusion, Cadiz, 11/1996 * Breuil, H. and Burkitt, M.C. : ‚ÄúRock Paintings of Southern Andalusia, a Description of the Neolithic and Copper Age Art Group‚Äù, Oxford University Press, 1929 * Cabr√©, J., Hernandez - Pacheco, E.: ‚ÄúIntroduction to the Study of Prehistoric Paintings of Southern Spain‚Äù, Works of the Commission of Paleontological and Prehistoric Investigations, No.3, National Museum of Natural Sciences, Madrid, 1914 == External links == {{commons category|Parque Natural Los Alcornocales}} * [http://www.arte-sur.com/tajo.htm Cave of the Edge of the Figures (Benalup - Old Houses)] * [http://www.canalandaluz.com/index.htm CULTURAL VESTIBULE - rock Art and prehistory] * [http://www.juntadeandalucia.es/medioambiente/servtc5/ventana/mostrarFicha.do?idEspacio=7410 Los Alcornocales Natural Park (in spanish)] [[Category:Rock art in Spain]] [[Category:Prehistoric art]] [[Category:Natural parks of Spain]] [[Category:Natural parks of Andalusia]] [[Category:Geography of the Province of C√°diz]] [[Category:Geography of the Province of M√°laga]] [[Category:Los Alcornocales Natural Park| ]]

{{For|the record label of the same name|Crammed Discs}} '''Made-to-measure''' (MTM) typically refers to custom clothing that is cut and sewn using a standard-sized base pattern. [[Suit (clothing)|Suits]] and [[sport coat]]s are the most common garments made-to-measure. The fit of a made-to-measure garment is expected to be superior to that of a [[ready-to-wear]] garment because made-to-measure garments are constructed to fit each customer individually based on a few body measurements to customize the pre-existing pattern. Made-to-measure garments always involve some form of [[standardization]] in the pattern and manufacturing, whereas [[bespoke tailoring]] is entirely made from scratch based on a customer's specifications with far more attention to minute fit details and using multiple fittings during the construction process. All else being equal, a made-to-measure garment will be more expensive than a ready-to-wear garment but cheaper than a bespoke one. "Custom made" most often refers to MTM. [[Country of origin]] makes a difference in pricing, with [[made in China]] MTM garments typically priced below [[made in Italy]] ready-to-wear.
== Overview == To order a made-to-measure garment, the customer's measurements are first taken by a made-to-measure retailer. Then a base pattern is selected that most closely corresponds with the customer‚Äôs measurements. This base pattern is altered to match the customer‚Äôs measurements. The garment is constructed from this altered pattern.
The primary benefits to the customer of made-to-measure clothing are that the garments will be well-fitted to the customer's body and the customer may have the opportunity to customize the fabric and detailing. The primary disadvantage of made-to-measure is that the customer must wait up to several weeks for the garment to be sewn and delivered. A typical price markup for a made-to-measure item is 15% over the price of its ready-to-wear counterpart.{{Citation needed|date=May 2010}}
Made-to-measure retailers often travel internationally meeting clients in cities, providing samples of the latest materials and styles.
Unlike [[bespoke tailoring|bespoke]] garments, which traditionally involves hand sewing, made-to-measure manufacturers use both machine- and hand-sewing. Made-to-measure also requires fewer fittings than bespoke, resulting in a shorter wait between customer measurement and garment delivery.
Made-to-measure is sometimes also referred to as personal [[tailoring]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/ae6e1c54-df24-11db-b5c9-000b5df10621.html|title=Just how personal can you get|last=Brooke|first=Simon|date=March 31, 2007|work=Financial Times|accessdate=2008-10-09}}</ref>
In recent years tailoring has evolved further with young companies like Artefact London, that make a blend of made-to-measure and bespoke approaches. A base pattern is used to gauge your measurements and your unique pattern is created electronically with all alterations accounted for prior to cutting. Thus alleviating the need for baste fitting that is mandatory in bespoke with very minor alterations (if any) needed at the fitting.
== Advertising Standards Authority ruling == In the [[United Kingdom]], the legal definition of ‚Äúmade-to-measure‚Äù has been conflated with [[bespoke tailoring]] by a ruling of the [[Advertising Standards Authority (United Kingdom)|Advertising Standards Authority]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asa.org.uk/asa/adjudications/Public/TF_ADJ_44555.htm |title=Sartoriani London |accessdate=2008-10-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081122150946/http://www.asa.org.uk/asa/adjudications/Public/TF_ADJ_44555.htm |archivedate=2008-11-22 |df= }}</ref> The ruling is based on the [[Oxford English Dictionary]] definition of bespoke as "made to order". While this ruling clarified the difference between bespoke and ready-to-wear, it had the effect of blurring the line between bespoke and made-to-measure.
The ruling established that a "made-to-measure suit would be cut, usually by machine, from an existing pattern, and adjusted according to the customer's measurements," while "a bespoke suit would be fully hand-made and the pattern cut from scratch, with an intermediary baste stage which involved a first fitting so that adjustments could be made to a half-made suit." The ruling concluded, however, that a "majority of people... would not expect that bespoke suit to be fully hand-made with the pattern cut from scratch," effectively equalizing the terms bespoke and made-to-measure.
While etymologist Michael Quinion observed that by definition "it was legitimate for a tailor offering clothes cut and sewn by machine to refer to them as bespoke, provided that they were made to the customer's measurements",<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldwidewords.org/qa/qa-bes4.htm |title= bespoke|accessdate=2008-10-09 |publisher=Michael Quinion |date= September 13, 2008}}</ref> since the traditional use of bespoke inside the tailoring community has been more nuanced than the Oxford definition,<ref name="Sim">{{cite web |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/0ea5cbf6-4eed-11dd-ba7c-000077b07658.html |title= The b-word: not cut and dried |accessdate=2008-10-10 |first=Josh | last=Sim |date= 2008-07-12 |work=Financial Times}}</ref> others concluded that the ASA "took a rather ignorant decision to declare that there is no difference between bespoke and made-to-measure."<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.mensflair.com/news/a-loss-to-sartorial-language.php |title = A loss to (sartorial) language |accessdate = 2008-10-10 |first = Simon |last = Crompton |date = 2008-07-01 |work = Men's Flair |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081021143340/http://www.mensflair.com/news/a-loss-to-sartorial-language.php |archivedate = 2008-10-21 |df = }}</ref>

'''Mark Zuckerberg book club''' aka '''A Year of Books''' was an online book club hosted by [[Mark Zuckerberg]] through his personal [[Facebook]] account started in January 2015.<ref name=chowdhry>{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/amitchowdhry/2015/01/05/mark-zuckerberg-book-club/ |title=Mark Zuckerberg Starts A Book Club As His New Year's Resolution |work=Forbes |author=Amit Chowdhry |date=January 5, 2015 |accessdate=February 2, 2015}}</ref> Zuckerberg made a book recommendation every two weeks for a year to his millions of Facebook followers.<ref name=apthirdpick/>
Zuckerberg came up with the idea as part of his New Year's Resolution for 2015 after Cynthia Greco, the Audience Development Manager for MediaOnePA/York Newspaper Company, suggested that Zuckerberg read a new book every month. Zuckerberg modified the idea to one book every two weeks and books which "emphasize learning about new cultures, beliefs, histories and technologies."<ref name=chowdhry/>

Huber]] |''[[Orwell's Revenge: The 1984 Palimpsest]]'' |<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/mark-zuckerberg-book-club-orwells-revenge-2015-4 |title=Why Mark Zuckerberg is reading 'Orwell's Revenge,' an unofficial sequel to '1984' |work=[[Business Insider]] |author=Richard Feloni |date=April 29, 2015 |accessdate=April 29, 2015}}</ref> |- |10 |May 14, 2015 |[[Michelle Alexander]] |''[[The New Jim Crow|The New Jim Crow: Mass Incarceration in the Age of Colorblindness]]'' |<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/mark-zuckerberg-the-new-jim-crow-2015-5 |title=Why Mark Zuckerberg wants everyone to read 'The New Jim Crow' |work=[[Business Insider]] |author=Richard Feloni |date=May 14, 2015|accessdate=June 20, 2015}}</ref> |- |11 |June 1, 2015 |[[Ibn Khaldun]] |''[[Muqaddimah]]'' |<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/mark-zuckerberg-the-muqaddimah-2015-6 |title=Why Mark Zuckerberg wants everyone to read the 14th-century Islamic book 'The Muqaddimah' |work=[[Business Insider]] |author=Richard Feloni |date=June 2, 2015|accessdate=June 20, 2015}}</ref> |- |12 | June 15, 2015 |[[Yuval Harari]] |''[[Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind]]'' |<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/mark-zuckerberg-recommends-sapiens-a-brief-history-of-humankind-2015-6 |title=Why Mark Zuckerberg wants everyone to read an Israeli historian's book about the human race |work=[[Business Insider]] |author=Richard Feloni |date=June 16, 2015|accessdate=June 20, 2015}}</ref> |- |13 |June 29, 2015 |[[Iain Banks]] |''[[The Player of Games]]'' |<ref>{{cite web |url=http://motherboard.vice.com/read/why-are-elon-musk-and-mark-zuckerberg-reading-utopian-sci-fi |title=Why Are Elon Musk and Mark Zuckerberg Reading Utopian Sci-Fi? |work=[[Vice (magazine)|Vice]] |author=Alix Jean-Pharuns |date=July 10, 2015 |accessdate=August 12, 2015}}</ref> |- |14 |July 14, 2015 |[[Vaclav Smil]] |''[[Energy: A Beginners Guide]]'' |<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/mark-zuckerberg-and-bill-gates-book-recommendation-2015-7 |title=Mark Zuckerberg wants everyone to read a book by Bill Gates' favorite author |work=[[Business Insider]] |author=Shana Lebowitz |date=July 16, 2015 |accessdate=August 12, 2015}}</ref> |- |15 |July 28, 2015 |[[Matt Ridley]] |''[[Genome (book)|Genome: The Autobiography of a Species in 23 Chapters]]'' |<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/mark-zuckerberg-recommends-matt-ridleys-genome-2015-7 |title=Why Mark Zuckerberg wants everyone to read this book about the evolution of man |work=[[Business Insider]] |author=Richard Feloni |date=July 28, 2015 |accessdate=August 12, 2015}}</ref> |- |16 |August 12, 2015 |[[William James]] |''[[The Varieties of Religious Experience|The Varieties of Religious Experience: A Study in Human Nature]]'' |<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/mark-zuckerberg-recommends-the-varieties-of-religious-experience-2015-8 |title=Why Mark Zuckerberg wants everyone to read this book about religion |work=[[Business Insider]] |author=Richard Feloni |date=August 12, 2015 |accessdate=August 12, 2015}}</ref> |- |17 |September 1, 2015 |[[Daryl Collins (author)|Daryl Collins]], [[Jonathan Morduch]], [[Stuart Rutherford]] |''[[Portfolios of the Poor: How the World's Poor Live on $2 a Day]]'' |<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/mark-zuckerberg-recommends-portfolios-of-the-poor-2015-9 |title=Why Mark Zuckerberg wants everyone to read about how the poor spend their money |work=[[Business Insider]] |author=Richard Feloni |date=September 1, 2015 |accessdate=September 17, 2015}}</ref> |- |18 |September 16, 2015 |[[Daron Acemoƒülu]], [[James A. Robinson (Harvard University)|James A. Robinson]] |''[[Why Nations Fail|Why Nations Fail: The Origins of Power, Prosperity, and Poverty]]'' |<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/mark-zuckerberg-recommends-why-nations-fail-2015-9 |title=Why Mark Zuckerberg wants everyone to read about the origins of global poverty |work=[[Business Insider]] |author=Richard Feloni |date=September 15, 2015 |accessdate=September 17, 2015}}</ref> |- |19 |September 29, 2015 |[[Matt Ridley]] |''[[The Rational Optimist: How Prosperity Evolves]]'' |<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/mark-zuckerberg-recommends-the-rational-optimist-2015-9 |title=Why Mark Zuckerberg wants everyone to read this book about 'idea sex' |work=[[Business Insider]] |author=Richard Feloni |date=September 29, 2015 |accessdate=October 23, 2015}}</ref> |- |20 |October 21, 2015 |[[Liu Cixin]] |''[[The Three-Body Problem (novel)|The Three-Body Problem]]'' |<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/mark-zuckerberg-recommends-the-three-body-problem-2015-10 |title=Why Mark Zuckerberg wants everyone to read this book that caused a sensation in China |work=[[Business Insider]] |author=Richard Feloni |date=October 21, 2015 |accessdate=October 23, 2015}}</ref> |- |21 |November 9, 2015 |[[Jon Gertner]] |''[[The Idea Factory: Bell Labs and the Great Age of American Innovation]]'' |<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/mark-zuckerberg-recommends-the-idea-factory-2015-11 |title=Why Mark Zuckerberg wants everyone to read about the lab that has won the most Nobel Prizes |work=[[Business Insider]] |author=Richard Feloni |date=November 9, 2015 |accessdate=November 10, 2015}}</ref> |- |22 |December 10, 2015 |[[Henry Kissinger]] |''[[World Order (book)|World Order]]'' |<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/why-mark-zuckerberg-is-reading-henry-kissingers-book-2015-12 |title=Why Mark Zuckerberg wants everyone to read Henry Kissinger's book about world order |work=[[Business Insider]] |author=Richard Feloni |date=December 10, 2015 |accessdate=December 10, 2015}}</ref> |- |23 |December 28, 2015 |[[David Deutsch]] |''[[The Beginning of Infinity|The Beginning of Infinity: Explanations that Transform the World]]'' |<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/why-mark-zuckerberg-is-reading-the-beginning-of-infinity-2015-12 |title=Why Mark Zuckerberg wants everyone to read a book that claims human potential is infinite |work=[[Business Insider]] |author=Richard Feloni |date=December 28, 2015|accessdate=December 28, 2015}}</ref> |}
==Reception== ''The Atlantic'' wrote that it "has the potential to be Oprahesque in its influence on book sales", in reference to the [[Oprah Book Club]] after the first selection by Mois√©s Na√≠m caused [[Amazon.com|Amazon]]'s stock to sell out.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2015/01/mark-zuckerbergs-book-club-could-be-much-bigger-than-it-looks/384207/ |title=Mark Zuckerberg's Book Club Could Be (Much) Bigger Than It Looks |work=The Atlantic |author=Adrienne LaFrance |date=January 5, 2015 |accessdate=February 2, 2015}}</ref> An article in ''[[The New Yorker]]'' made a similar comparison to [[Oprah]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2015/01/19/zuckerberg-bump |title=The Zuckerberg Bump |work=The New Yorker |author=Lizzie Widdicombe |date=January 19, 2015 |accessdate=February 2, 2015}}</ref> ''[[The Associated Press]]'' noted that the second selection by Steven Pinker did not result in any increase in sales according to [[Nielsen BookScan]] data.<ref name=apthirdpick/>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}

page.title: Mus√©e international d'Art na√Øf Anatole Jakovsky

revision.comment: Migrate {{Infobox museum}} coordinates parameters to {{Coord}}, see [[Wikipedia:Coordinates in infoboxes]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox museum |name = Mus√©e international d'Art na√Øf Anatole Jakovsky |image = |imagesize = |caption = |map_type = France Nice |map_caption = |coordinates = {{coord|43.686111|7.232778|display=inline}} |established = 1982 |dissolved = |location = Avenue de Fabron
06000 [[Nice]], [[France]] |type = [[Art museum]] |visitors = 20,000 per year |director = |curator = |publictransit = |website = }} The '''Mus√©e international d'Art na√Øf Anatole Jakovsky''' (Eng.: Anatole Jakovsky International Museum of Naive Art) is a [[museum]] located in [[Nice]], which displays 18-to-21st century works specialized in [[naive art]]. The museum was inaugurated on 5 March 1982. ==History and description== The museum was housed in the Ch√¢teau Saint H√©l√®ne which was the former residence of perfumer Fran√ßois Coty, and is located in a large park. In 1930, his ex-wife Yvonne decide to order changes in the building by Nice architect H. Malgaud who removed the sets designed by Aaron Messiah. Her daughter Christiane Coty sold the castle to the city of Nice on 6 April 1973, and the building was eventually transformed into a museum, which opened in 1982.{{cite web |title=Mus√©e International d'Art Na√Øf ANATOLE JAKOVSKY |url=http://www.nice.fr/Culture/Musees-et-expositions/Musee-d-Art-Naif |publisher=nice.fr |language=French |accessdate=13 July 2011}} The works are composed of paintings, sculptures, drawings, posters by painters such as [[Henri Rousseau]], [[S√©raphine Louis]], [[Grandma Moses]], O'Brady, Rimbert, Ivan and Josip G√©n√©ralic, Bauchant, Vivin, Lackovic, Haddelsey, Ligabue, Vivancos, among others...{{cite web |title=Mus√©e international d'Art na√Øf Anatole Jakovsky |url=http://www.evene.fr/culture/lieux/musee-international-d-art-naif-anatole-jakovsky-709.php |publisher=evene.fr |language=French |accessdate=13 July 2011}} The collection come from donations of Ren√©e and [[Anatole Jakovsky]] (to whom the museum owes its current name), and the [[Centre Georges Pompidou]]. The giant statues in the garden were created by Fr√©d√©ric Lanovsky. The museum has about 20,000 visitors per year, and 600 works from 27 countries.{{cite journal |title=NICE: Les na√Øfs √† la plage |url=http://www.lexpress.fr/informations/nice-les-naifs-a-la-plage_595142.html |journal=[[L'Express (France)|L'Express]] |publisher=Express-Roularta Group |place=Paris |date=1 July 1993 |language=French |accessdate=13 July 2011}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{coord|43|41|10|N|7|13|58|E|region:FR_type:landmark_source:kolossus-frwiki|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:International d'Art naif Anatole Jakovsky}} [[Category:Museums in Nice]] [[Category:Na√Øve art|Musee International d'Art naif Anatole Jakovsky]] [[Category:Art museums established in 1982]] [[Category:1982 establishments in France]]

page.title: National Union of Writers and Artists of Cuba

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.2)
revision.text:
'''The National Union of Writers and Artists of Cuba''' ('''Uni√≥n Nacional de Escritores y Artistas de Cuba''', '''UNEAC''') is a social, cultural and professional organization of writers, musicians, actors, painters, sculptors, and artist of different genres. It was founded on August 22, 1961, by the Cuban [[poet]], [[Nicolas Guillen]]. Initially their objective was uniting the intellectuals within the young [[Cuban Revolution]] to maintain a genuine Cuban culture. The group issued ''La Gaceta de Cuba'' beginning in 1962.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.uneac.org.cu/publicaciones/la-gaceta-de-cuba |accessdate=25 February 2017 |title=La Gaceta de Cuba |publisher=UNEAC |language=es }}</ref> Cuban violinist and professor [[Evelio Tieles]] was President of the Music Section from 1977 to 1984.<ref name="Evelio">{{cite web|url=http://www.ecured.cu/Evelio_Tieles_Ferrer|title=Evelio Tieles Ferrer-Ecured|accessdate=June 15, 2016}}</ref>
[[Manuel V√°zquez Portal]] was expelled from UNEAC because of his dissident views.<ref name="RWB-Manuel Vasquez Portal">{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/article.php3?id_article=10839|title=Journalist Manuel V√°zquez Portal released|publisher=[[Reporters Without Borders]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040803060850/http://www.rsf.org/article.php3?id_article=10839|archivedate=2004-08-03|df=}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Ediciones El Puente]] * [[Roger Aguilar Labrada]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.uneac.org.cu/ National Union of Writers and Artists of Cuba webpage]
[[Category:Cultural organizations in Cuba]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1961]] [[Category:1961 establishments in Cuba]]
{{Art-org-stub}} {{Cuba-stub}}

The term '''New Leipzig School''' ({{lang-de|Neue Leipziger Schule}}) refers to a movement in modern German painting. The usage and origins of this term are debated.<ref>E.g. [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/10/02/AR2006100201431.html New Leipzig School Provides a Study in Hype] Blake Gopnik, ''[[The Washington Post]]'', 3 October 2006. {{en icon}}</ref>
==History and characteristics== The "old" Leipzig School was a term used by art journalists which had become established by some time no later than 1977, and the involvement of [[Werner T√ºbke]], [[Wolfgang Mattheuer]] and [[Bernhard Heisig]]<ref name=nyt>[https://www.nytimes.com/2006/01/08/magazine/08leipzig.html?_r=2&pagewanted=print The New Leipzig School] Arthur Lubow, ''[[The New York Times]]'', 8 January 2006. {{en icon}}</ref><ref name=welt>[https://www.welt.de/wams_print/article1746491/Das_Unbehagen_mit_der_Neuen_Leipziger_Schule.html Das Unbehagen mit der Neuen Leipziger Schule] ''[[Die Welt]]'', 2 March 2008. {{de icon}}</ref> with [[documenta]] 6. The students of those artists, including Sighard Gille and [[Arno Rink]], can be seen as the second generation of the Leipzig School.
The New Leipzig School, as a third generation, relates to the post-[[Reunification of Germany|reunification]] climate of modern Germany<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/how-the-leipzig-artists-are-taking-on-the-world-477557.html How the Leipzig artists are taking on the world] Tony Paterson, ''[[The Independent]]'', 10 May 2006. {{en icon}}</ref> and is closely linked with the [[Hochschule f√ºr Grafik und Buchkunst Leipzig]]. It usually refers to the students of Gille and Rink,<ref name=zeit>[http://www.zeit.de/2005/30/Leipziger-Maler Neuen Leipziger Schule: Die stille Revolte] Christian Sch√ºle, ''[[Die Zeit]]'', 21 July 2005. {{de icon}} Available in English [http://www.signandsight.com/features/287.html here].</ref> but occasionally those of Rolf Kuhrt or even Heisig or T√ºbke. Its works tend to be characterised by a combination of figurative and abstract elements. Clear messages, which were characteristic of the "first" Leipzig generation of painters, are no longer present.
The list of painters that are classified in this school is not fixed, but has included [[Neo Rauch]],<ref name="nyt"/><ref name=welt /><ref name=zeit /><ref>[http://www.artinfo.com/news/story/25190/neo-rauch/ The AI Interview: Neo Rauch] Robert Ayers, ''[[ARTINFO]]'', 6 June 2007. {{en icon}}</ref> [[Christoph Ruckh√§berle]]<ref name=nyt /><ref name=welt /><ref name=zeit /> and [[Matthias Weischer]].<ref name=nyt /><ref name=welt /><ref name=zeit /> Others who have been associated with the term include [[Tim Eitel]], [[Tilo Baumg√§rtel]], [[Christian Brandl]], [[David Schnell]], [[Martin Kobe]], [[Michael Triegel]], [[Ulf Puder]], [[Rosa Loy]] and [[Axel Krause]].
A significant role in the success of the "New Leipzig School" was played by the gallery owner Gerd Harry Lybke,<ref name=nyt /><ref name=welt /><ref name=zeit /> who introduced the works of Rauch in particular to the globally important American art market. Other Leipzig artists were able to achieve international acclaim in the wake of this, such as the Greek-German painter [[Aris Kalaizis]]. Parallels can be seen between these successes and those of the [[Young British Artists]]. Also crucial for the Leipzig painters' success was Matthias Kleindienst,<ref name=nyt /><ref name=goethe>[http://www.goethe.de/kue/bku/msi/mui/en4832829.htm International Hotspot, Hip Community or Art Ghetto? ‚Äì the Leipziger Baumwollspinnerei] Sigrun Hellmich, [[Goethe-Institut]], July 2009. {{en icon}}</ref> gallery owner and head of the [[woodcut]]ting workshop at the [[Hochschule f√ºr Grafik und Buchkunst Leipzig|Hochschule]], whose search for talent paved the way for many young Leipzig artists, including Weischer. Another major factor in their market success was the "LIGA" art project, established in [[Berlin]] in 2002 under the direction of Christian Ehrentraut, a former collaborator with Lybke.<ref name=nyt />
Most of the artists tagged as "Leipzig School" members reject the classification. The art historical community has also consistently avoided the term on account of its vagueness and imprecision. However, it is widely used as a label and marketing tool in the world of art dealership.<ref name=welt />
Many painters and galleries associated with the School are based in the "Music District" (''Musikviertel'') in the south-western part of the inner city, and more recently at the [[Leipziger Baumwollspinnerei|Leipzig Cotton Mill]] in Plagwitz.<ref name=nyt /><ref name=welt /><ref name=zeit /><ref name=goethe />
==References== <references/>
==External links== * [http://www.zeit.de/2006/29/LeipzigerSchule Leipziger Schule: Geborgtes Leben] Hanno Rauterberg, ''[[Die Zeit]]'', 14 July 2006. {{de icon}}
[[Category:Contemporary art]] [[Category:Culture in Leipzig]] [[Category:German artist groups and collectives]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Organization | name = Ozark Actors Theatre |image= |image_border= |size= |caption = Ozark Actors Theatre April 2015 |map = |msize = |mcaption = |abbreviation = |motto = |formation = 1987 |extinction = |type = |status = |purpose = |headquarters = [[Rolla, Missouri]] |region_served = |membership = |leader_title = Stage Manager |leader_name = Jim Welch |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [http://www.ozarkactorstheatre.org/ ozarkactorstheatre.org] }}
'''Ozark Actors Theatre''' is an [[Actors' Equity Association|Equity]]<ref name="newdirector">{{cite web|url=http://visitrolla.com/ozark-actors-theatre-appoints-new-artistic-director/|title=Ozark Actors Theatre Appoints New Artistic Director - Visit Rolla|work=Visit Rolla}}</ref> theater company in [[Rolla, Missouri]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.missourilife.com/travel/the-ozark-actors-theatre-in-rolla/|title=The Ozark Actors Theatre in Rolla|work=MissouriLife.com}}</ref> founded in 1987 by pianist Gail Andrews-Hintz and founding Artistic Director F. Reed Brown<ref>http://www.waynesvilledailyguide.com/article/20120625/NEWS/306259901</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ozarkactorstheatre.org/about-us/|title=About Us|work=Ozark Actors Theatre}}</ref> with the help of actress Cindy Beger and her friend Kathy Pukas.<ref>Eddie O'Neill, [http://www.therolladailynews.com/article/20130725/NEWS/130729433/?Start=1 "The little theater that could ... and still does 26 seasons later"], ''[[The Rolla Daily News]]'', July 25, 2013.</ref> In 1993, The Cedar Street Playhouse became the home of Ozark Actors Theatre.<ref>http://www.therolladailynews.com/article/20151113/news/151119483</ref><ref>http://www.brewerscience.com/news/471/59/Brewer-Science-Underwrites-Ozark-Actors-Theatre-to-Bring-Neil-Simon-s-FOOLS-to-Rolla</ref> Ozark Actors Theatre quickly gained a reputation for doing quality theatrical productions, and drew acclaim in Missouri and nationwide.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.questia.com/newspaper/1P2-32999634/good-theater-is-where-you-find-it-in-rolla|title="Good Theater Is Where You Find It- in Rolla" by Newmark, Judith - St Louis Post-Dispatch (MO), June 16, 1996 {{!}} Online Research Library: Questia|website=www.questia.com|access-date=2016-10-05}}</ref> In 2010 Jason Cannon became the artistic director,<ref> Judith Newmark, [http://www.stltoday.com/entertainment/arts-and-theatre/culture-club/jason-cannon-will-head-ozark-actors-theatre/article_dd2dacf0-d1db-11df-a47e-00127992bc8b.html " Jason Cannon will head Ozark Actors Theatre"], ''[[St. Louis Post-Dispatch]]'', October 10, 2010.</ref> and Pamela Reckamp took the position in 2015.<ref name="newdirector"/>
The only [[Actors' Equity Association|Equity]] theatre in the area,<ref>Judith Newmark, [https://www.questia.com/newspaper/1P2-32999634/good-theater-is-where-you-find-it-in-rolla "Good Theater Is Where You Find It- in Rolla"], ''[[St. Louis Post-Dispatch]]'', June 16, 1996.</ref> they have produced more than 100 shows and are affiliated with the [[Missouri Arts Council]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.laduenews.com/diversions/arts-entertainment/importance-of-being-earnest-still-charms-with-its-wit-theater/article_89c891a4-29b2-11e5-832f-a7945da732b9.html|title='Importance of Being Earnest' Still Charms with Its Wit: Theater Review|author=Mark Bretz|date=13 July 2015|work=Ladue News}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.laduenews.com/diversions/arts-entertainment/joseph-and-the-amazing-technicolor-dreamcoat-musical-review/article_8a90b6b4-0d04-11e4-8bbe-0017a43b2370.html|title=Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat: Musical Review|author=Mark Bretz|date=16 July 2014|work=Ladue News}}</ref> ==List of Shows== {{colbegin}} '''1988''' * ''[[Godspell]]'' * ''[[The Diviners (play)|The Diviners]]'' * ''[[Greater Tuna]]'' * ''Magic to Do''
'''1989''' * ''Bernstein: Music of the Maestro'' * ''[[I Do! I Do!]]'' * ''Voices'' * ''[[The Boys Next Door (play)|The Boys Next Door]]'' * ''[[The Foreigner (play)|The Foreigner]]''
'''1990''' * ''Broadway: The Last 10 Years'' * ''[[The Duck Variations]]'' * ''Graceland'' * ''Litko'' * ''Savage Love'' * ''[[Talley's Folly]]'' * ''[[The House of Blue Leaves]]'' * ''Lou Gehrig Did Not Die of Cancer'' * ''[[Quilters (musical)|Quilters]]'' * ''[[A Christmas Carol]]'' * ''[[The Actor's Nightmare]]''
'''1991''' * ''[[A Christmas Carol]]'' * ''[[The Fantasticks]]'' * ''[[Barefoot in the Park]]'' * ''[[The Elephant Man (play)|The Elephant Man]]'' * ''The Songs of [[Stephen Sondheim]]'' * ''The Voice of the Prairie''
'''1992''' * ''[[Nunsense]]'' * ''The Golden Age of Broadway'' * ''I Hate Hamlet'' * ''Jazz at Castleman'' * ''A Scent of Honeysuckle'' * ''[[The Actor's Nightmare]]''
'''1993''' * ''[[Love Letters (play)|Love Letters]]'' * ''[[Nunsense]] II: The Second Coming''
'''1994''' * ''[[Dames at Sea]]'' * ''The Gifts of the Magi'' * ''[[Marvin's Room (play)|Marvin's Room]]'' * ''Sea Horse'' * ''[[Lend Me a Tenor (musical)|Lend Me a Tenor]]''
'''1995''' * ''Abundance'' * ''[[Smoke on the Mountain]]''
'''1996''' * ''In White America'' * ''On the Air'' * ''[[Cotton Patch Gospel]]'' * ''The Golden Age of Entertainment'' * ''[[The Nerd]]''
'''1997''' * ''A Command Performance'' * ''Happy Birthday, You're Dead!'' * ''[[Bye Bye Birdie]]'' * ''[[Steel Magnolias (play)|Steel Magnolias]]''
'''1998''' * ''[[Big River (musical)|Big River]]'' * ''[[All I Really Need to Know I Learned in Kindergarten]]'' * ''Wedding Bell Blues''
'''1999''' * ''Aunt Tilly's Funeral'' * ''[[The Music Man]]'' * ''[[Driving Miss Daisy (play)|Driving Miss Daisy]]'' * ''[[Little Shop of Horrors (musical)|Little Shop of Horrors]]''
'''2000''' * ''[[Once Upon a Mattress]]'' * ''Grace and Glorie'' * ''To Kill a Mockingbird''
'''2001''' * ''[[Annie (musical)|Annie]]'' * ''Art'' * ''[[Arsenic and Old Lace (play)|Arsenic and Old Lace]]'' * ''[[The Best Christmas Pageant Ever]]''
'''2002''' * ''[[Oklahoma!]]'' * ''[[You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown]]''
'''2003''' * ''[[Oliver!]]'' * ''[[Always (Patsy Cline album)|Always... Patsy Cline]]''
'''2004''' * ''Route 66: A Celebration of America's Mainstreet'' * ''[[Fiddler on the Roof]]'' * ''[[Wait Until Dark]]'' * ''[[Nunsense|Nuncrackers]]''
'''2005''' * ''[[The Sound of Music]]'' * ''[[Forever Plaid]]'' * ''[[The Odd Couple (play)|The Odd Couple]]'' * ''A Christmas Survival Guide''
'''2006''' * ''[[Gypsy (musical)|Gypsy]]'' * ''Musical Comedy Murders of 1940'' * ''[[Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat]]''
'''2007''' * ''[[Godspell]]'' * ''[[Anything Goes]]'' * ''[[Moon Over Buffalo]]'' * ''[[Big: the musical]]'' * ''[[White Christmas (musical)|White Christmas]]''
